checkpoints.event: We depart from the uni
On the motorway we encounter a Harry-Potter-style bus carrying plants
Unfortunate woman waves us down for petrol or for directions to the nearest petrol station, of which we can offer neither
What stranger road signs could you encounter than:
“Sudden gunfire”
“Tanks crossing”
Reach Lulworth car park
Groups organisation: a short/medium group of 27 (myself included) and a long group of 19. Thus we start walking
At the small Lulworth Cove beach we backtrack and pick a different path uphill
Break in the fog; draw distance 30m
Dog heads towards a water recipient but instead of just drinking jumps in.
Lee: That is a metaphor for my life right now

Reaching a street, somebody has the impression that there should be 28 in our group and we are missing a person. We repeatedly count 27 heads. But according to the above we're supposed to be 27, and on that observation we resume walking.
Break
Vote to continue pushing forward rather than have lunch in thick clouds by a massive pile of horse shit
Break
Lunch break, still in the clouds
Lunch break ends
Break
Break before what we think to be the final descent before Durdle Door
We progress through the fog and an extraneous hill is revealed which we had forgotten about
We meet the long group above Durdle Door beach, which they'd already been to. A whole bunch then split in search for toilets, while the remaining long group start walking a final loop.
Gone swimming
Everyone reunites on the beach
Group picture with the arch
Izzy calls names from the list to ensure everyone is present. Then we leave the beach for the final stretch towards the fish&chips shop
Fish&chips
Minibus 2 leaves car park
Minibus 2 arrives at Highfield Interchange
Walk begins
A tired rough-nighter contemplates the possibility to give up the walk, but soon changes his mind
Most open field ever
Bentley Wood signpost crossroads
We encounter Hook & Glove pub
We got bitten while sitting in Pitton
Lunch break opposite the Silver Plough pub
Lunch break ends
We get directionally misplaced and take a detour (no we're NOT lost!) and thus see a deer
Panel: Danger! Deer stalking, keep out
Richard: So that deer was stalking us!
Clarendon Palace Royal Court ruins. Rest break. Thomas water-fans the sleepers.
Great spire in the sky
Walk ends
Walk stars
Consecutive tunnels
A comprehensive discussion on junction choices
Overly long toilet break in vicinity of pubs; we suspect the toiletees stopped for a pint and left us to dry out in the sun
Two cars come from opposite directions on this narrow road and meet exactly, but exactly, where we're standing
Lunch break by a very conveniently placed ice cream shop
Lunch break ends
Richard: Are we going through the trees?
Thomas: No, we're just waiting in the shade.
John beats the record of how late in the afternoon he gets someone to reply 'Good morning' to his greeting 'Good morning'
A moment of confusion in memory of the once-not-so-packed pubs
Walk ends at Crown & Anchor

accounts.what: I am astounded by the ambition that a few fellow hikers can spend on something so inconsequential as getting strangers to reply 'Good morning' when it's no longer morning. Just after 12pm it was funny; at 2pm it started to be concerning; at 4pm it became downright unfathomable.

checkpoints.event: Walk begins
Lunch break
Lunch break ends
Giant Sequoia
Walk ends
Minibus 2 set off
Sam drives the minibus as she would a rollercoaster, and I mean that in a good way
Shaun's playlist for the first leg of the journey deserves a qual-o-meter of 100%
The man that can't be moved
What's the opposite of quick? Common people would say slow. We hillwalkers say scenic. Isn't it amazing how we manage to see the bright side of everything, even satnavs with less than ideal settings.
Minibus 1 arrives at first M6 services, where we shall have a McDonald's excuse of a dinner (well, all but the most self-respectful of us)
Minibus 2 arrives at first M6 services
Minibus 1 leaves services
Minibus 2 leaves services
Now Roger drives minibus 2 and Shaun's playlist is still going. I cannot really comment on the driving as it's all straight flat motorway. Music qual-o-meter for this leg of the journey: 84%
Minibus 1 arrives at subsequent services
Minibus 2 arrives at subsequent services
Both minibuses leave services
Shaun now drives through the more difficult section of the journey, his playlist presumably still going. Unfortunately I fall asleep again and therefore cannot comment on these facts.
Minibus 2 arrives at accommodation: Windermere Chalet
Minibus 1 arrives at accommodation
Lights off
I get up
Breakfast starts being served
Breakfast stops being served
Briefing for “a prompt 08:30 departure”
We split into a “challenging” group of 11, led by Byron, and a “less challenging” (fun?) group of 15, led by Serena
Minibus 1 (the “challenging” group) leaves for Swirrel Edge
After much manoeuvre, minibus 1 manages to pull out of the car park and actually depart
After much fiddling with satnavs, minibus 1 really actually truly starts moving
Driving hardcore level 1000: How to overtake a streak of 8 cyclists with a minibus on a narrow, snakey-ass road
Roof rack containers start coming loose and rattling against the window, so we pull over and take them down before they completely fly off
We (the challenging group) arrive into a relevant car park
Begin march of approach
Begin effective climb
Breath-catch at a significant checkpoint
Stop on a pile of rocks from where we can see the summit
Split of edges: 5 of us (Roger, Hoy, Thomas & Maurice & Nick) form an even more challenging group, taking left towards Striding edge
We (the slightly less challenging group) emerge onto the plateau at alternative summit 1, namely a rock pile
Woosh past trig point, which might be the official summit
Why would there be a cycle up here, let alone a dozen?!
The challenging group rejoin at alternative summit 2, namely a stick
We establish radio contact with the fun group and they report having stopped for lunch and to attend to an asthma inconvenience. We ourselves stop for lunch
(Semi)group photo by the stick
Meanwhile the fun group report being able to see us over the valley. It's cold and we decide not to wait for them
Now it's suddenly sunny and we stop for reciprocal photo service by the trig point
Being descent
Wind… Stahp!
Fun group radio us as they have lost 3 people who walked ahead. They immediately find them
Tail of challenging group reaches minibus
Brief shopping
We arrive at accommodation
Byron: Hmmm… Serena has the key.
Everyone: (Most desolated exclamation ever)
Teo: If you have a hairpin we can probably lockpick this.
Nick: I may not have a hairpin, but I do have a boot!
Byron brings bleak news about the fun group, so we need to
get dinner started ahead of their arrival, but for that we need proper knives, for which we must pay a deposit,
towards which I lend him £10 to give the manager
Wild Serena appears, soon followed by the entire fun group
Dinner is served; food qual-o-meter reads 99%
We have acquired a table of 12 people of which none is strictly English
By this time a vast majority of us has gone to sleep
I get up; immediately I see breakfast going on
Pack up etc
We encounter a slight paradox in terms of people and bags distribution
Minibuses move
We reach the car park by Coniston visitor centre
Tom realises his rucksack is missing
After searching all minibus roof storages, we wager there was a mixup with another large group packing their vans next to us leading to Tom's rucksack being misplaced
Serena rings the bunkhouse and asks about the rucksack
Bunkhouse calls back and says it's been found
We split into a challenging group (led by Byron), a mid-speed group (led by Serena), and a Lakes group (led by Tom); the latter will detour back to the bunkhouse to recover the lost rucksack
The challenging group (13 people) escape pavement into nature. The road is already scrambly despite being nowhere near a mountain top yet
We reach a most infamous–looking rubble area (old quarry buildings), where 3–way contact is established and Byron persuades Manuel to wait for Serena's group
Lunch break on some big rocks by a lake (this being the Lake District, such a location label is quite useless)
Summit
Being descent, longer route
Respiro by Goats' Water (lake). Serena is not reachable by radio. We spot some brave climbers on the nearly vertical rock face opposite and attempt to zoom in on them with various cameras.
Back into the town, we reach out to the other teams; seeing they're all still hiking, we have a free choice of pub to wait for them in and so choose the Crown Inn
Team Lakes arrive at the pub
We leave the pub
Team middle start gathering by the minibuses
Minibus 2 leaves
Minibus race on the motorway (insurance companies don't read this!)
Sam keeps driving
We stop in Chester to have dinner at the George Wetherspoon
Table 34 is the most eventful dinner table in a decade
We all leave Whetherspoon
On this leg of the journey, Roger drives, and Shaun's playlist suffers a momentary Disney shift
We exit the motorway for a final break and driver swap
Byron: I don't think Serena and the others will stop here, because they missed the turn at the roundabout and ended up back on the motorway.
Back on the road
Shaun drives the final stretch, which will be the more daunting one because of people being dropped off at their doors. Music qual-o-meter for the whole journey back: 88%
Refuel
Drop off Glen Eyre
Drop off Cantell School roundabout
Drop off Mayfield road
Drop off City Gateway
Drop off Wessex Lane. I am hereby no longer aware of the whereabouts of the minibus
Begin walk
James: Should we look for a path or should we go cross-country?… Let's go cross-country!
Teo: Platform Grass for the 9:50 CrossCountry service to the Next Path. Calling at Next Path only.
A man sets us up for the bogs
Horses in the field
Serena: They won't talk to me!
Teo: Even though they know perfect English?
As we enter Lyndhurst on a narrow-ass sidewalk, a lorry speeds around a bend in the road, tilts over, and pushes us towards a high wall, allowing about 20cm on either side of our heads
Lunch around toilets building
Head to chocolate fair
Caution! Child throwing tantrum across path.
After much toilet-disfunctionality-related kerfuffle, we leave Lyndhurst centre
We reach the renowned Green Area on the edge of Brockenhurst
Walk ends

I (Teo) should be employed with trains – people claim – because not only can I near-perfectly immitate platform announcements, but I also know to pull open a door which seems unwilling to slide open by itself.

name: Unofficial Official West Sussex day walk

checkpoints.event: We get on platform 2 for the 9:32 Southern train towards London Victoria. Platform panel says “Terminates here”. We look at the closed doors reluctantly and the platform attendant tells us to walk in.
We find seats and get comfortable.
In-train announcement says that “this train is no longer in public service.” We disappointedly get off. Meanwhile, platform panel says “9:32 London Victoria”

We wander aimlessly around the station; we can't completely overhaul our walk plans because of an arrangement with a member who has already gone to Chichester, earlier in the morning, for a pre-walk run
Back on platform 2, we board another train which looks suspiciously like the previous; platform panel says “10:13 Brighton”
We were supposed to start the walk, but in fact we've barley left Southampton

We'd have had 3 minutes to change in Chichester to catch the 11:14 stopping service back to Fishbourne were it not for the first train astonishingly being 2 minutes early. Richard runs across the bridge and almost boards the wrong train, which would have taken him back to Emsworth or all the way to Havant.
Walk begins from Fishbourne, 50 minutes later than it should have
We proudly notice the group has, for the first time in ages, 100% appropriate footwear

Planned walk takes a turn for the worse when a forset we were planning to cross turns out to be a fenced off conservation area. We are forced to walk on some roads and to listen to Richard incessantly say that we should have stuck to the plan regardless.
The middle of nowhere we thought this road to be going through suddenly becomes a post-modern posh villa village
We finally make it back to non-asphalt area and stop for lunch near some wooden benches on what could generously be called a beach
Lunch break ends
Teo: “This mud is so wrong! It's just unlike all the muds we've been through recently.”
“Holy crap it's a crab” as we walk over (and further smash) the shards of what used to be a living crab's shell

A certain member who shall respectfully remain unnamed repeatedly asks strangers for directions, despite there existing current and future day walk secretaries who carry maps, compasses, and a perfectly functional sense of direction

Slightly high tide means the ford over a section of Bosham channel is not trivially traversable on foot. Once again it is proven that drying one's feet/complaining/laughing about it and walking around the long (dry) way take approximately equal amounts of time.
Accidental stop by ice cream van
45° pause
Walk ends at the Barleycorn in Nutbourne after 19.6km

name: Unofficial Official Taddiford Gap Coastal Walk

checkpoints.event: Walk begins from New Milton station
We reach a roundabout much discussed on the map, but it looks like just an ordinary roundabout
Bogs (Richard receives death threats)
Dogs
Break by Milford on Sea Kiosk and beach recently cleared of warfare metalworks
Lunch break
We reach the easy side of Hurst castle

We reach the dark side of Hurst castle, which for matters of high tides requires walking a certain length of knee-deep ocean water. In spite of everybody else, I (Teo) decide to detour the whole entire rest of the castle to get on the other side of this wet and salty adventure.
It turns out parkouing all the dry contour of Hurst castle and drying one's feet/complaining about it take approximately equal amounts of time

As we walk on a half flooded road, a car comes from ahead. Despite being a car and despite the flood being on its half of the road, the car pulls over onto our side, forcing us to walk through the flood.
Art gallery in Milford on Sea
Walk ends at The Ship Inn after 23km,
but then we change our minds
and (while Matt R preorders through an app just to spite us... OK perhaps he was hungry)
we end up in Wetherspoons,
where we drink and eat and eat and drink
until we leave
and reach the station to catch the 18:29 northbound.
Minibuses set off from before the Union building
Tom drives and DJs minibus 2. Music quality on my personal, non-relatable scale: 96%
Minibus 2 arrives at Bridport and stops in a car park, then we wait for the others inside for a bit
Izzy: It's arctic winds, let's go back home!
Minibus 1 arrives.
Tom: You overtook us twice, we never overtook you, yet we arrived first!
James: Yea, we took a wrong turn…

After final map clarifications, we split into 2 groups. The fast (and longer distance covering) group, led by Byron, is formed originally of 17 people, myself (Teo) included; the slow (and fun?) group, led by Serena, is formed of 13 people. As such, we set off for the walk.
Asphalt ends and real climb begins
We (the fast group) reach the first hilltop, where there are winds! Though nothing like what's going to be waiting for us in the evening.
Izzy and Matt R fall back to the slow group (due to Izzy's purposefully very heavy rucksack that she brought for her personal training, for which we congratulate her) equalising group sizes
And we're at sea/river level again. Clearly this is Jurassic Coast Deluxe.
We reached the top of the tallest hill visible; meanwhile the slow group radio in and report having stopped on the beach (perhaps for a swim? Did I mishear that?)
We miss a clear “coastal path diversion” sign and end up in an overgrown landslide
Snow starts to settle on hat tops and lands. / Crosswinds and snowflakes at high speed draw bands / Across my vision. It looks so bizarre: / I watch my life on an old VCR.
Coffee/water & bread break (Joe is bae)
Golden Cap trig point
Golden Cap tombstone

After debating wind, temperature, and stomach conditions, we stop for lunch under the precarious protection from wind granted by bushes, dirt bumps, and the Golden Cap tombstone itself (I know it's not a tombstone but it looks awfully like one)
Lunch break ends
Significant bench stop

We hit a critical turning point from which we start heading back toward Bridport; meanwhile the slow group have just reached the Golden Cap tombstone and Serena radios out her dismay of Tom's unexemplary behaviour of standing up on the Golden Cap trig point
Stanton St Gabriel
Along a flooded muddy road, attempting to bypass the bogs by holding onto the right fence and climbing on the side,
we catch up with the slow group, who have just reached safe terrain after the same muddy manoeuvre
and are now attending a barbed wire first aid event
but we steam past as we have no sense of compassion

Merging back into the outbound path, we stop halfway up a hill on a bench for a water break. Looking back we see the slow group and notice they're not making much progress. We ask them if everything is fine and they radio back informing us of their in progress biscuit break
We're half a mile from the town according to a signpost, while the slow group report being half an hour behind us
We reach the town seafront asphalt street
In front of The George pub, we employ my mud brush to prevent catastrophic damage to the pub's carpets
We take seats in the pub, having walked 25.5 km according to Richard's distance tracker
Pints of Thatcher's and other beverages fly onto our table; my face is burning red from the sudden change in temperature and airflow conditions
The fast part of the slow group, consisting of 9 people, arrive at the pub
Through the pub window, we get a visual of the remaining 6 people approaching
Izzy & Matt R arrive at the pub
Food starts being served and people who don't remember what they'd preorderer are alarmed, because only Serena has the list of preorders but she is still out, closing the convoy
The slow part of the slow group arrive at the pub finally and the walk unequivocally ends
We all leave the pub
Minibuses depart
Shaun drives and DJs minibus 2. Music quality on my personal, non-relatable scale: 72%
Minibus 2 arrives in the designated parking spot with a full tank and 15 dead-legged hillwalkers
Happy group photo of 25 people who are about to walk a marathon, oblivious to how f*** long that actually is
Make a move
First person realises they should have used the loo before we left for a 26 mile walk
We reach Riverside Park, but unforecast rain starts
Despite valiant attempts we fail to push a paddle-boarder off his board by blowing at him from the opposite side of the river
Wide road cross at trash pile cranes
Quick catch-up @5.1mi
Reachard (the event of Richard reaching us)
Public facilities (toilet) break @6.6mi
Shoe-stealing mud occurs at a flooded bend in the road. Only vested members with vested walking boots make it through without significant effort
"Tom! Slow down!!!" (Richard's voice is like a walkie talkie, but better: it doesn't need batteries)
Regathering finally after dogs distraction through elevated forest path @9mi
"Let's just say it's mud"
Pass by Bursledon stn @11.6mi. We almost lose Izzy, but we don't

Past halfway @13.4mi and walkie talkies are finally called to action to keep contact between the front and back of the group which now stretches over several hundred yards, beyond reliable visual contact (despite the path being coastal)
Ferry shelter with no ferry
Lunch pub, Rising Sun @14.6mi (or 13.9mi or 15.6mi depending whose distance tracker you trust)
Extra beer appears on the table that no one claims
Spare burger is brought to the table thanks to a confusion in the order. We look at it suspiciously thinking that perhaps the first one to touch it will be forced to pay for it
Everyone vanishes from the tables
Out of pub, half-happy group photo of 26 people who are yet to walk almost as much as they have already
Map/detour recalculation @16.7mi
Confusion!
Rest on beach corner 10 min @19.4mi
James appears! (but we won't count him as having done the walk)
Approximately 3mi left
Quest: We should get back before the sun goes down.
Small police force show before Fareham stn
Hit Fareham stn. Various distance trackers say: 26.5/26.2/25.3mi
Cathedral
Rams in middle of Salisbury
Serena's bench break
Biscuit break
Lunch break
Waiting for catch-up at 4 dirt paths crossroads
Re entry – walk ends at usual pub
Most of us leave or have already left the pub to catch the 16:33 back
Board train, with some people missing it due to excessive fumbling-around
Walk starts, with 21 people
Bogs occur
Spontaneous biscuit break
Richard: Where are we? Teo: Hartley Wintney. Richard: That's correct, 'cause it's hardly windy!
Richard attempts to direct the 3 people who missed the train in our direction using live location over dodgy 4G signal
Lunch break
The 3 people manage to find us
Lunch break ends
Path is interrupted by a horse. A lady appears and ties the horse so we can pass.
Hit edge of Hook town
Walk ends at pub: Old White Hart
Somebody who left the pub early and got to the station to get the 14.48 train realises she lost her phone in the pub. Meanwhile, we are eating burgers and can confirm an abandoned phone on a bench.
Phone is retrieved, but train has been missed
We get the 15.18 train to Basingstoke. Then onwards to Southampton

accounts.what: All recorded history of the club's walks that we can access confirm that this is the very first time we have done a walk in this area.

checkpoints.event: I arrive at the Stable
Richard hijacks part of the group and takes them to Sprinkles
The rest of the group leave the Stable
Front group arrive at the Flying Dutchman, sans Izzy who was here ages before thanks to a taxi
Richard's group arrive at the Flying Dutchman
Shots x2 aka pocket emptification 5000
Tom the President acquires a faulty shoulder
The faulty shoulder (and its possessor) is taken to A&E
Arrive at the afterparty place
Failed attempt at a game of Twister
Nothing happens. I become bored and leave.
Walk starts (sans Tom who stops at Costa for breakfast). We believe we have 24 people, which may or may not be true.
James calls Tom to find out he's in the company of a few stray people
Tom and 8 others merge at the back of the main group, yielding a total of 29, because maths
Lunch break
Lunch break ends
Walk ends in distress because we don't want to take responsibility for people being lost in the crowds around the Winchester Christmas markets
Walk begins.
Lunch break
Phone drop calamity. 2 people branch off and backtrack in search of the lost phone.
Garden stairs madness
Marwell Zoo Car Park reloaded, with more thorns
Hit station. Walk ends.
The 2 people rejoin
Train ticket madness
Walk starts from Salisbury station with 29 people
Confusion around cathedral diversion and minor navigation error
'Nice room!'
Two more people join
Lunch
Walk ends. 8 people detach and go to the pub, the rest head up to the train station

name: Winchester Fireworks and Treasure Hunt combo

checkpoints.event: Congregation of treasure hunt participants outside Winchester station and quest sheets distribution
Team JTTM (My team. Our actual team name was so irrelevant I can't remember it.) leaves the station
JTTM: 2. Social media challenge launched
JTTM: 1. Train station
JTTM: 23. WSA
JTTM: 8. Dog
JTTM: 4. Winchester Market
JTTM: 29. Old Mill
JTTM: 25. River Itchen. 19. Swans
JTTM: 27. Sport of love
JTTM: 28. St Catherine's Hill Titanic enactment
JTTM: 31. Landscape
JTTM: 19. Ducks
JTTM: 20. Viaduct battle enactment
JTTM: 11. Birdie
JTTM: 16. King Alfred statue
JTTM: 10. Winchester Cathedral Lion King enactment
JTTM: 5. Sunglasses
JTTM: 26. Where Rosie would work
JTTM: 15. Round table
JTTM: Collapse at pub
JTTM: 13. Pay Rosie a visit
We join the procession
Bonfire is lit
Fireworks set off
Fireworks die (bonfire still lives)
(Very packed) train home
Met at interchange ready to depart
Planned leaving time
I (Teo) arrive at meeting point
Arshad shows up!
Minibus 2 leaves ('2' is the number painted on the minibus and has no mathematical or logical significance; the other minibus is numbered '3')
Actually left due to SUSU’s appalling management system with the minibuses (they originally thought we only had one minibus booked, and wanted to do an oil check on all the buses before we left)
Car takes A34 then M4 to Swindon before turning north. Minibuses stay on A34 and get caught up with traffic due to accidents near Oxford
Minibus 2: Google commercial (Google maps predicts with an accuracy of seconds the beginning of a long traffic jam behind an accident)
Minibus 2: Police. Move over. 4 cars in a crash.
Car (Eilish, Serena, Nan Zhou and I (Tom)) stop for dinner in Tewkesbury services. Minibuses 2&3 have just cleared A34 traffic by Oxford.
Minibus 2: Dinner stop. I mean McDonald's poisoning session. Also driver swap.
Minibus 2: Burger metaphor
Minibus 2: British metaphor
Minibus 2: Re driver swap
Car arrives at bunkhouses (after missing the turning). Minibuses aren’t in sight.
Minibus 3 overtakes Minibus 2
Minibus 2: Song quest
Still no sign of minibuses, Joe had informed us (Tom&co) earlier they should be approx half an hour behind us.
For uninvestigated reasons of high stupidity, Minibus 3 stops and turns in the road claiming we're going the wrong way. We follow them into what will become an excerpt from hell.
Excerpt from hell begins

'Keep driving! Drive already!!!' (Weirdest encounter ever: A woman walking her dog in the dead of night versus two Uni of Southampton minibuses on a narrow-ass country road; and I don't know which is weirder)
Minibus 2 hits accommodation
After varying phone calls or various degrees of panic, minibus 2 finally shows up. Minibus 3 is apparently stuck approx 5 miles from bunkhouses.
Serena: There is some toilet paper, but I think it's in the other minibus.
Teo: There is some in the toilets, but it's soggy. And there's a caterpillar in the sink, but other than that all good.
Arrive at stranded minibus.
People from Minibus 3 have been rescued and brought to accommodation
started writing this out of boredom
No sign of recovery yet and when we (Tom&co) phoned again the guy couldn’t even pronounce the name of the garage that’s coming to help.
Discover voice message from 10 mins ago from recovery. Phoned back and described situation and best approach.
Recovery guy arrives! (In a very well kitted out defender I might add)
Finally get moving again!
Minibus 3 arrives!
Bedtime! (for Tom&co)
Presumably ​somebody wakes up
I (Teo) wake up
Everyone apart from those who got back at 0530 (Daisy, Jacob, Arshad, Matt and I), are up and preparing to go out for a day’s walk, short local one is planned.
Stash distribution
Main group (21 people) set off for main walk
Main group: Muddy roads orientation séance
Sam: My whole leg just vanished! (mud hole terrors)
Entire 6am bedtime group is up and preparing for their walk.
Main group: Windy lunch
After a midday breakfast of porridge, the 5 minibus campers set off for a local walk, taking a different route to the other group.
Stranded Minibus group stop for lunch.
Main group: Group photo and comfortable mother nature
Main group: Navigational error due to fence and forest on map being absent in reality
End of bogs
Nope!
Stranded minibus group makes it back to the bunkhouse, cold, muddy and damp but overall still a reasonably good walk. No sign of other group.

Phone contact made with other group, their ‘short local’ walk turned out to be shorter and more ambitious than originally planned. They are approx 10 mins away. Unsure who is going to manage Snowdon the next day.
Main group: Fast half hit accommodation
Main group: Slow half hit accommodation
Leave for Bangor for pub for dinner etc
Navigational error due to inconsistent satnavs / road vehicle height restrictions
We arrive at the local weatherspoons, The Black Bull. Ordering quickly turns into a competition to see who can have the most calories in their meal.
Joe has won the calorie competition having managed just over 3000. Everyone heads back to the minibuses and travels to the bunkhouses.
The firebasket is lit, Arshad gets shouted at for letting smoke into doors whilst trying to take a long-exposure. Alcohol fire-breathing fails dismally.
The firebasket has been put out, everyone is in bed and looking forward to the extra hours sleep from the clocks going back. Snowdon in the morning!
I (Teo) sleep
Daylight Saving Time ends
Rise and shine!
Room 7 wake up call
Everyone is packing up, hoping to be out by 0900
Minibus 2 leaves
Parking madness
Pen-y-pass Car Park is full, after driving up and down the road the minibuses drop people at the carpark then park about half an hour’s hike away.
Plan split madness

Daisy and I (Tom) reach the pen-y-pass carpark. The decision is taken to split into two groups, one to take Pyg to the summit and come back down miners, the other to go up miners and down Pyg without ascending all the way to the summit.
Strong group (20 people) head up Pyg track towards Snowdon summit
Strong group: The complaints start to surface.... the fast walkers are too fast. The slow walkers are too slow, and no-one is keeping pace. After a brief pause the group gets going as a whole again.
Strong group: Contact is made with Jacob and Shaun, they are about 15 mins behind us and catching up reasonably rapidly.
Strong group: Lunch
Strong group hit railway
Strong group: Summit photo session
Strong group: Coffee shop
Strong group: After dosing up on caffeine we start the descent.
Strong group: At wire-fenced rocks corner, Daisy, Matt and I (Tom) split off and go ahead to try and get the minibuses in time for everyone else getting down.
Strong group: Throwing pebbles into lake
We (Tom&co) arrive at the carpark but after failing to locate Sam we start the extra half an hour hike to the minibuses.
We all leave the long-damned car park
Minibus 3: Stop for food in Telford services.
Dinner stop and minibus 2 driver swap
We approach a roundabout. We brake. I (Tom) drop my coffee. It is a sad day.
Minibus 2: Re driver swap
Minibus 3 arrives back in Southampton! We park up, then between 4 of us manage to carry all the random Away Trip kit back to my house.
I (Teo) reach home
I (Tom) am home. The trip is over. It was good fun. But now the bed is calling.

accounts.what: The stranded minibus situation! Minibus 2&3 turned off the A5 for some reason (According to minibus 2, turn off was due to navigation error with Arshad using a map not a satnav). Whilst going up a hill, minibus 3 starts to get clutch problems. Minibus 2 makes it up the hill, minibus 3 decides clutch is fucked, hill ahead is far too steep, try and turn around. Through some witchcraft, minibus 3 ends up with front against a stone wall and rear wheels stuck in mud. After adding stones to try and provide extra traction and not succeeding, minibus 2 is despatched to the bottom of the hill to collect 3’s passengers. Minibus 3’s passengers hike 1km to minibus 2 and get back to bunkhouses safely. Minibus 3 is now left stranded awaiting assistance. After a very long wait, and a lack of decent communication from the RAC, the recovery vehicle arrives. Defender 90 equipped with winch, snorkel, and all manner of gadgets in the back. After a failed attempt with traction mats, and a failed attempt to squeeze the defender around the rear of the minibus, we begin to debate the feasibility of winching the minibus to a straightened orientation. After this turns out to be futile without damaging the fence, wall or minibus, metal traction ladders are brought into play. These prove to be more effective and with the aid of 4 people pushing from the front, the minibus finally finds some grip. Under direction of the recovery guy, the minibus is eventually orientated to face up the hill, paper work is filled in and we make a move. Clutch is still dodgy but we just about make it up the hill!

checkpoints.event: Beautiful rainbow above Southampton
Walk begins with 21 people
Former club president joins
We run into road which doesn't exist on the map, causing great confusion
Water & biscuit break
I trip over the one single stone in a whole mile-wide field
Serious rain strikes
We find a decently sheltered area to stop for lunch
Serious rain ends
Lunch break ends
Selected path on map is marked as private property in reality, forcing us to walk on a boring road
Walk ends
15:54 train picks us up from Shawford
Gathering & platform change. Trains are in shambles because of engineering works
Le Ferry FAIL. Not enough room for 90-odd people
Effective start of walk from Yarmouth
First session of 'wait for the people lagging at the back'
Hit viewpoint for Needles. 2 people detach from group and backtrack for reasons related to British transport system ridiculousness
Top-of-the-impossibly-abrupt-hill crisis strikes and the group divides into the 'slow group' (52 people) who will go to Tennyson monument and the 'fast group' (38 people) who won't
Aforementioned groups further split into groups
The slow group of the fast group meet the fast group of the slow group and form the medium group
Spaghettification reaches record levels as people try their individual best to reach the 18:05 ferry
The fast group of the fast group and the fast group of the medium group are on the ferry

The slow group of the medium group wait for the slow group of the slow group (because we're civilised people!), then enter Yarmouth only to divide again between the fish&chips shop and the pub. Walk effectively ends
A couple dozen people sit on the pavement outside the overfull fish&chips shop
The group of slow groups take the ferry
The group of slow groups finally return to Southampton Central
